intro: Serapias pseudocordigera, commonly known as the Corsican orchid, is a rare and specialized plant native to the Mediterranean region, particularly Corsica and Sardinia. It is a member of the orchid family (Orchidaceae) and exhibits unique floral morphology with brightly colored, spurred petals. The plant typically grows in rocky or calcareous soils, thriving in sunny, well-drained environments. Its flowers are adapted for specific pollinators, such as bees and flies, and it has a short flowering period in late spring. Due to habitat loss and limited distribution, Serapias pseudocordigera is considered a vulnerable species.
